oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Pikeville Chapel AME Zion Church: correspondence
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Knight, Carolyne L.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Pikeville Chapel African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church
P.O Box 243, East Valley Road, Pikeville, Bledsoe Co., TN
Correspondence from Carolyne L. Knight, Director of the Bledsoe Public Library to Dr. Carroll Van West informing him about historic preservation problem at the Dr. Ross House

Pikeville African Methodist Episcopal Church was built ca. 1870 and is believed to be the oldest rural African American Church building in Tennessee. At times during its long history it served multiple congregations. The church building also served as a public school, known as Lincoln Academy, that served the Black population of the Pikeville area until the new Lincoln School opened in 1925 with support of the Rosenwald Fund. From its founding throughout the Jim Crow era, the setting and location of the church was significant to its association with African-American ethnic heritage. Laying on the east bank of the Sequatchie River, the church was physically segregated from the remainder of Pikeville. It was next -to-town, but clearly not part of town. The church was still in use at the time of its nomination to the National Register.

Bledsoe County Public Library
July 23, 1998 Dr. Carroll Van West ~ MTSU Box 80 Murfreesboro, Tennessee 37132 Dear Dr. West, I am sending you some additional information on the AME Zion Methodist Church here in Pikeville. It includes a copy of the deed and a copy of a speech given by Miss Robnett concerning the church. Thank you for your advice on th~ Dr. Ross House. The mantel will be a problem. ~apparently was moved from the righ t bedroom (parlor). sometime in the first part of the century and now we do not know what to do. When the work first started it was moved back downstairs ( where I think it ori ginally was ) and then back wh~re we found it. The doors we are thi nking about changing are antique but not original to the house. Those two doors were removed before we aquired the house. We have not removed any trees except for those white pines that were planted during the 1960's. They were damaging the house and the roots were causing the fence to come apart. I have passed your letter along to Mr. Collier where I hope it will do some good about the old Dr . Ross off ice and the 1920' garage. Thank you for your help on this project. See you in october. Sincerely, Carolyne L . Knight Director 102 E. Cumberland Ave. I P.O. Box 465 I Pikeville, TN 37367 I (423) 447-2817
